thread.title: UPDATE 1-U.S. banks gird for Brexit-style tumult following Tuesday election - Business Insider
thread.title_full: UPDATE 1-U.S. banks gird for Brexit-style tumult following Tuesday election - Business Insider

posts.author: Reuters
posts.title: UPDATE 1-U.S. banks gird for Brexit-style tumult following Tuesday election - Business Insider
posts.text:
(Adds details from Wells Fargo, Bank of America) 
By Olivia Oran 
Nov 7 (Reuters) - U.S. banks, including Morgan Stanley , JPMorgan Chase & Co and Goldman Sachs Group Inc , are bracing for potential tumult on financial markets in the wake of Tuesday's U.S. election. 
Bank preparations ahead of the U.S. election reflect their experience following Britain's shock vote to leave the European Union in June, when the S&P 500 fell 3.6 percent the day after the poll. 
Morgan Stanley told staff to consider using stop-loss orders, an automated trading mechanism that is meant to sell an investor's position as soon as a stock hits a preset level, if the election result causes trading volumes and volatility to spike. 
The bank also told advisers in its wealth management unit to prepare for election-related conversations with clients and pointed them to relevant pieces of research, according to a Nov. 7 memo reviewed by Reuters. 
Traders expect U.S. stock prices to swing by about 2 percent in either direction on Wednesday, the day after the election, based on the price of S&P 500 index options. Options on the PowerShares QQQ Trust Russell 2000 ETF, are pricing similarly large swings before the week is out. 
Some banks are projecting a more extreme drop in the event of a victory for Republican Donald Trump, with Citigroup Inc estimating that a Trump victory could trigger a 3 percent to 5 percent selloff for the S&P 500. 
U.S. stocks rose on Monday as Democrat Hillary Clinton's prospects brightened after the Federal Bureau of Investigation said it would not press criminal charges related to her use of a private email server. 
Investors have tended to see Clinton as a more status quo candidate, while Trump's stances on foreign policy, trade and immigration have unnerved the market. 
After the election, Morgan Stanley will hold a call for financial advisers and clients with Chief Investment Officer Mike Wilson on Wednesday morning. 
Goldman Sachs is also hosting a call for its private wealth clients led by Chief Investment Officer Sharmin Mossavar-Rahmani and members of Washington lobbying groups Elmendorf Ryan and CGCN Group, according to an invitation sent to clients. 
More than half of the stock and bond fund managers polled by Northern Trust in the third quarter said they expected the election to cause a large increase in market volatility. 
On Tuesday night, when results begin to come in, JPMorgan will have additional traders on duty in New York to back up its Asian trading teams in case of surges in volume, said bank spokesman Brian Marchiony. 
The extra staffing is similar to what the bank did during Britain's vote to leave the European Union, he said. 
On Wednesday morning, JPMorgan will hold conference calls to discuss the election results and investment implications with customers, including private banking clients, investment managers and institutional clients. 
A Citigroup spokeswoman described similar plans, including overnight staff in New York on the trading floor. 
Bank of America Corp and Wells Fargo & Co are also hosting calls for members of their wealth management divisions. 
(Additional reporting by David Henry, Elizabeth Dilts and Saqib Ahmed in New York; Editing by Carmel Crimmins, Dan Grebler and Lisa Shumaker) Read the original article on Reuters . Copyright 2016. Follow Reuters on Twitter . More from Reuters:

thread.title: Bank of America's stock falls after analyst abandons bullish rating - MarketWatch
thread.title_full: Bank of America's stock falls after analyst abandons bullish rating - MarketWatch

posts.author: Tomi Kilgore
posts.title: Bank of America's stock falls after analyst abandons bullish rating - MarketWatch
posts.text: Shares of Bank of America Corp. BAC, -0.62% shed 0.8% in morning trade, to pull back from the highest close of the year in the previous session, after Deutsche Bank analyst Matt O'Connor indicated he was no longer bullish given the lack of upside potential. O'Connor cut his rating to hold from buy. He kepts his stock price target at $18, which was less than 7% above current levels. For Deutsche Bank, a bullish buy rating means the expected total return for the stock is 10% or more over a 12-month period. "Upside to the stock seems increasingly dependent on a pickup in economic activity, higher interest rates, and stronger capital market revenues as more company specific positives...seemed priced in," O'Connor wrote in a note to clients. He also downgraded Citizens Financial Group Inc. CFG, -2.39% to hold from buy. Bank of America's stock had closed Monday up 2.8% at the highest level since Dec. 30. Year to date, it has ticked up 0.3%, while the SPDR Financial ETF XLF, -0.53% has gained 2.7% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.20% has tacked on 4.1%.

thread.title: Merrill+ Visa Signature 50,000 Point Bonus Offer Worth Up to $1000
thread.title_full: Merrill+ Visa Signature 50,000 Point Bonus Offer Worth Up to $1000

posts.author: Gary Leff
posts.title: Merrill+ Visa Signature 50,000 Point Bonus Offer Worth Up to $1000
posts.text:
by Gary Leff on November 8, 2016 
Merrill Lynch was acquired by Bank of America during the financial crises. It was effectively a bail out. Of course that put Bank of America on the hook for a good deal of liability. It also means that they issue the Merrill Lynch credit card , and they apparently want new cardmembers because they’ve got an aggressive sign up bonus for the product: 50,000 points after $3,000 in spend within the first 90 days. 
This is a no annual fee card that will give you a Delta SkyClub membership after $50,000 spend in a year (or choose a $200 travel credit instead). I wonder how they’re able to do this given Delta’s co-brand exclusivity with American Express or rather I’m surprised that they’re able to do this and that the American Express agreement doesn’t preclude it. 
Seattle SkyClub 
Points are worth a penny apiece as statement credits or two cents apiece towards travel under some specific circumstances, so the signup bonus can buy $1000 in travel. 
You have to redeem 25,000 at a time. So a $500 ticket can be redeemed for 25,000 points. But your points are only worth a penny apiece towards amounts over $500 in airfare (redeemed in 2500 point increments). 
The 2 cent value for your first $500 only applies to American, British Airways, Delta, and United. Other carriers get you just 1.67 cents in value for that first $500 (30,000 points for up to $500 in airfare). 
Basically you want to play ‘Price is Right’ with this card’s redemptions: as close to a $500 airline ticket as possible without going over, and restricted to airlines where you get the best value. 
It’s a good signup bonus from an issuer many don’t have a ton of cards from, but there are some hoops to go through to maximize value.

thread.title: Justices weigh fair lending lawsuit against Bank of America, Wells Fargo
thread.title_full: Justices weigh fair lending lawsuit against Bank of America, Wells Fargo

posts.author: jbyrnes@thehill.com (Lydia Wheeler)
posts.title: Justices weigh fair lending lawsuit against Bank of America, Wells Fargo
posts.text:
Justices weigh fair lending lawsuit against Bank of America, Wells Fargo Greg Nash By Lydia Wheeler - 11/08/16 12:35 PM EST 
The Supreme Court appeared divided Tuesday over whether the city of Miami could sue Bank of America and Wells Fargo for discriminating against African-American and Latino residents when issuing mortgage loans. 
Justice Elena Kagan struggled with the bank’s argument that Miami had not shown that discrimination was the primary cause of the city's injuries. ADVERTISEMENT Under the Fair Housing Act (FHA), she said, the city is considered an “aggrieved person.”
“This is their own interest in maintaining their communities free of the kind of racial discrimination that the Act says causes neighborhood blight,” she said. 
Miami claims Wells Fargo and Bank of America violated the FHA by steering minority residents toward predatory mortgages that caused properties throughout the city to fall into foreclosure. 
As a result, the city is seeking monetary damages for the property tax revenue it lost due to neighborhood blight and the money it had to spend on city services responding to it, such as police, fire and building inspectors. 
Wells Fargo and Bank of America, however, claim Miami is only trying to recoup the money it lost in the 2008 financial crisis and that it doesn’t have standing to sue under the FHA. 
Miami’s attorney Robert Peck denied that claim. 
“If the 2008 financial crisis was, indeed, the purpose of this lawsuit, then the statute of limitations, which is two years, would have ended this lawsuit a long time ago,” he said. 
But Chief Justice John Roberts and Justice Anthony Kennedy wanted to know if neighborhood businesses that have a vested interest in a vibrant community would also be able to claim they were injured by the bank’s discriminatory practices. 
Peck argued they would not because they are commercial property owners. 
“The city has a special interest in fair housing and an integrated community that the FHA is designed to vindicate,” he said. “The employer does not. The local dry cleaner does not." 
Because the damages being sought by the city don't appear to be going to the residents who received the bad loans, Kennedy asked if the city considered itself a direct victim of discrimination. 
When Peck said it does, Roberts pushed back, arguing the city's injuries are a result of the direct injury its residents suffered. 
"You don't start with you," he said. "I understand your argument that you're down the line, but I don't see how you can say that your loss of property taxes is a direct injury." 
The banks' attorney, Neal Katyal, warned the justices that a ruling in favor of Miami would allow any city to claim it has been discriminated against under the Fair Housing Act. 
“There are 19,300 cities in America," he said. "If you adopt their theory, you would be allowing all of them to bring complaints just like this." 
Updated: 1:07 p.m.

thread.title: Supreme Court hears housing bias case involving Bank of America, Wells Fargo
thread.title_full: Supreme Court hears housing bias case involving Bank of America, Wells Fargo

posts.author:
Greg Stohr 
Bloomberg News
posts.title: Supreme Court hears housing bias case involving Bank of America, Wells Fargo
posts.text:
Order Reprint of this Story 
U.S. Supreme Court justices signaled they may divide over the ability of cities to use the Fair Housing Act to sue banks for discriminatory lending practices that contribute to urban blight. 
Hearing arguments in Washington as the country went to the polls to choose the next president, the high court grappled with a case that grew out of the subprime mortgage crisis. 
A federal appeals court read the Fair Housing Act as giving Miami the right to sue Bank of America Corp., Wells Fargo & Co. and Citigroup Inc. Miami says the banks targeted minorities for riskier and costly loans, leading to foreclosures that cost the city property-tax revenues and forced it to spend more on police and fire services. 
Some of the court’s liberal justices indicated through their questions that they would vote to let the cases go forward. Justice Elena Kagan suggested the dispute was at the heart of what the landmark 1968 law was designed to address. 
“Everything about this complaint is about racial segregation, it seems to me,” Kagan said. 
But two potential swing votes, Chief Justice John Roberts and Justice Anthony Kennedy, suggested they saw a need to limit the types of suits that could be filed under the law. Roberts called Miami’s injury “derivative.” 
“I don’t see how you can say that your loss of property taxes is a direct injury,” he told the city’s lawyer, Robert Peck. 
The Election Day argument was a relatively low-key affair, with Justices Samuel Alito and Clarence Thomas asking no questions and Justice Stephen Breyer saying far less than usual. One possibility is that the shorthanded court could divide 4-4, an outcome that would let Miami press ahead without setting a nationwide precedent. 
Charlotte-based Bank of America and San Francisco-based Wells Fargo say Congress didn’t intend to allow private lawsuits by a plaintiff who wasn’t a victim of discrimination and whose interests are so far removed from the alleged wrongdoing. 
The banks’ lawyer, Neal Katyal, said the city was “borrowing someone else’s anti-discrimination interests.” Citigroup isn’t directly involved in the Supreme Court appeal. 
The Fair Housing Act says an “aggrieved person” may sue. In 2011 the Supreme Court interpreted similar language in the federal job-discrimination law to mean that only people within the law’s “zone of interests” could sue. 
Miami and the Obama administration say the 2011 decision left intact earlier rulings suggesting that the Fair Housing Act was drafted broadly. They say the only restrictions on who can sue come from the Constitution and its requirement that a plaintiff suffered an injury that a court would be able to redress. 
Similar suits have been filed around the country, including claims by Los Angeles and three Georgia counties. 
Peck told the court that the cities of Baltimore and Memphis, Tennessee, had settled similar claims for less than $10 million. 
“We not talking about huge sums of money,” he said. 
The cases are Bank of America v. Miami, 15-1111, and Wells Fargo v. Miami, 15-1112. Related content

thread.title: Kindred Healthcare's (KND) CEO Benjamin Breier on Q3 2016 Results - Earnings Call Transcript
thread.title_full: Kindred Healthcare's (KND) CEO Benjamin Breier on Q3 2016 Results - Earnings Call Transcript

posts.title: Kindred Healthcare's (KND) CEO Benjamin Breier on Q3 2016 Results - Earnings Call Transcript
posts.text: Kevin Fischbeck - Bank of America, Merrill Lynch Gary Lieberman - Wells Fargo Securities Operator Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Kindred Healthcare third quarter 2016 conference call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions, I'll turn the conference over to Eddie Jones. Eddie, please go ahead. Eddie Jones Thank you and good morning. Welcome to the Kindred Healthcare third-quarter 2016 conference call. Before the Company's presentation, I would like to read the cautionary statement. This conference call includes forward-looking statements as defined in Section 27A of the Securities Act of 1933, and Section 21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, which involves a number of risks and uncertainties. Such forward-looking statements are based on management's current expectations and include known and unknown risks, uncertainties, and other factors, many of which the Company and its management are unable to predict or control, that may cause the Company's actual results and performance to differ materially from any future results or performance expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. The Company cautions participants that any forward-looking information is not a guarantee of future performance and that actual results could differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking information. The Company refers you to its reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including the Company's annual report on Form 10-K, the Company's other reports filed periodically with the SEC, and its press release regarding the third-quarter operating results, for a discussion of these forward-looking statements and other factors that could affect these forward-looking statements. Many of these factors are beyond the control of the Company and its management. The Company cautions investors that any forward-looking statements made by the Company are not guarantees of future performance. The information being provided today is as of this date only, and the Company disclaims any obligation to update any such factors or to announce publicly the results of any revisions to any of the forward-looking statements to reflect future events or developments. Certain references to core EBITDAR, core operating cash flows, and core diluted earnings per share, as well as other non-GAAP disclosures, have been reconciled to the Company's consolidated operating results and are available on the Company's website, www.kindredhealthcare.com. It is now my pleasure to introduce the participants on today's call: Ben Breier, President and Chief Executive Officer of Kindred; and Stephen Farber, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. I will now turn the call over to Mr. Breier. Ben Breier Thanks, Eddie, and good morning, everyone. Let me start as I usually do by extending my deep appreciation on behalf of the entire leadership team to our more than 100,000 teammates across the country. Each day our partners at Kindred work hard to improve the lives of more than 1 million patients we care for annually. The excellent care delivery and clinical outcomes we generate are the direct results of their efforts. Last night we reported third quarter results within our guidance range. Like many of our peers who have already reported, results across our various lines of business were mixed. We had outstanding performance in certain businesses, such as Kindred at Home and Kindred rehab services, and challenging results in other businesses, specifically those with skilled nursing center exposure. Before I dive into a detailed discussion of our results in each business, I'd like to outline the proactive strategic steps we are taking to position Kindred for long-term success against the backdrop of dynamic changes in the healthcare service industry. Last night we announced the strategic decision to exit the skilled nursing facility business, which is the final step in a process that began for us 15 years ago when Kindred operated over 300 skilled nursing facilities. A full exit of this business, together with the significant cost realignment initiative we are undertaking in connection with the exit, are substantial steps forward in our effort to continue to transform Kindred's strategy and growth profile to enhance shareholder value. We're pleased to be working with Ventas to finalize an agreement that will create value for Ventas and Kindred shareholders, and facilitate Kindred's exit from the skilled nursing business. Over the past few years, we have dramatically changed the composition of Kindred; and, along with that, the drivers of growth and profitability. Following completion of the exit of the skilled nursing business and associated cost realignment initiative, Kindred's earnings stream, cash flow generation, and leverage profile will be substantially improved. Over time, when complete, we expect approximately half of Kindred's future EBIT to come from Kindred at Home, the nation's largest home health hospice and community care platform. We expect roughly one quarter of Kindred's future EBIT to come from our rebalanced hospital division, and the remaining one quarter to come from rehabilitation services division, which includes one of the largest and fastest growing inpatient rehab facility businesses in the country. The proactive decision to exit the skilled nursing center business in its entirety is a gating event in Kindred's history. So let me provide a little bit more detail on our decision. Reducing our exposure to the skilled nursing business has been a strategic objective for some time, given the utilization and operating headwinds facing the sector, coupled with our focus on higher growth, higher margin, and less capital intensive businesses, like home health and hospice. While our nursing center division represents less than 15% of our consolidated revenues, its negative impact on cash flow and earnings is noteworthy, especially this year. Our exposure to the challenges facing the nursing center industry are expected to amount to $40 million to $50 million worse than our 2016 operating plan, upon which our initial 2016 guidance was based. Fortunately, given our diversified portfolio of post acute businesses, the impact of the skilled nursing business on the Kindred enterprise has been somewhat muted. That said, the drag from headwinds in this business is clearly offsetting solid performance in our other divisions. Our decision to reduce guidance or the balance of 2016, exit the skilled nursing center business in its entirety, and substantially reduce our overhead is a direct result of these challenges. Of significant importance around the changes is the removal of large rent and CapEx obligations that have been escalating over time. We expect to reduce our annual rent obligations by approximately $90 million, and annual capital expenditures by approximately $30 million. As part of this decision, we also expect to optimize our overhead by eliminating approximately $70 million to $100 million of divisional and corporate overhead, above the facility level, much of which is associated with supporting our skilled nursing facilities. As investors who have followed Kindred for some time know, Kindred has a long history of delivering on synergies and cost-saving initiatives, and we have confidence we will achieve this goal. For example, on the Gentiva deal, we achieved $91 million of synergies, a savings at the high end of our already aggressive expectations. There have been some, upon hearing our announcement, who have questioned whether this is a change in strategy. To be clear: our strategy has not changed at all. Although we are exiting the skilled nursing facility business as an owner operator, we continue to consider skilled nursing a critical element of the care continuum. We will work closely with many high quality providers of skilled nursing facilities across the country to care for patients in need as part of our ongoing Continue the Care initiatives. Our primary issue has been that with our current portfolio, we haven't had enough of a skilled nursing facility presence to accommodate our local market needs. Going forward, we plan to organize, affiliate, and partner with local and regional networks of skilled nursing facilities owned by other organizations. And we expect that our sale of Kindred's skilled nursing facilities will bring additional opportunities for employment and career growth for our teammates by being a part of a broader and deeper local skilled nursing network. We look forward to finding the right home for our patients, our employees, and our facilities. As we look forward on what the future holds for Kindred Healthcare, I want to remind investors about the meaningful progress we're making in our move to build new, value based capabilities and further differentiate Kindred from the post acute industry. Our post acute benefits and management capabilities will be driven by our unique bundle of technology enabled care management capabilities and assets in local markets we both own and partner with. Earlier this year, we announced an initiative with Inovalon to create a set of data driven tools to drive a post acute site placement, lower readmissions, and lower cost of care. We've made tremendous progress in developing these care management capabilities and expect to be able to deploy these tools in the market in the very near future. This will help support bundling, ACO, and other value-based payment initiatives. Kindred's Continue the Care initiatives, creating a clinical continuum between Kindred's service lines has taken hold, creating seamless transitions between post-acute sites of care that serve as an important foundation for managing patients in an ACO and bundling context. And as we will discuss more in coming months, our growing contact center is emerging as a centralized hub for patient care management, both for Kindred and our partners. And we continue to participate in our own pilot on alternative payment models, including participation in a Model 3 post-acute-only Medicare bundling demonstration, and being a majority owner in a primary care physician Medicare ACO, Silver State. And that really represents our approach to positioning Kindred to succeed in a value based world. We have the continuum; we are rapidly developing the care management capabilities to manage patients across the continuum; and you should expect to see us partnering with hospital systems in a variety of ways so that together we are positioned to succeed in the future. Rather than going alone, for example, with only Model 3 post acute bundles, our strategy is to partner with acute hospital systems to provide seamless care at a lower price point from hospital to home. Now let me spend a few minutes on each of our divisions, starting with Kindred at Home. Kindred at Home delivered another solid quarter. As the largest home health hospice and community care platform in the nation, it remains one of the most exciting growth stories at Kindred. During the quarter we were busy integrating the business we acquired in Arkansas to become the largest in home provider in that state. We also completed the largest system conversion in Kindred's history, moving all of our branches onto a single, unified clinical platform called KindredLink. And we did it without the business interruption that many companies who are going through similar transitions have experienced. For the third quarter, the Kindred at Home division delivered core EBITDAR growth of 4.1% over the same quarter last year on revenue growth of 5.5%. Our home health service line saw 3.7% episodic admission growth in the quarter, and core EBITDAR growth of 10.2%. But importantly, same-store episodic growth was 6.9% in this business. Our hospice operations also achieved solid growth in the quarter, with revenue growing 4.1% on same-store admissions, a robust 8.3%. The third quarter marked the third straight quarter of admission and census growth in this business. Our community care business, a community-based delivery model that plays an important role in managing complex patient population health issues, helped to drive Kindred at Home's solid performance in the quarter. Including the Arkansas community care business acquired in the quarter, our community care business now boasts annual revenues of nearly $300 million. The seamless integration of the Gentiva acquisition and the continued growth and success of our Kindred at Home division underscores our confidence that this business will be a major driver of value creation for our enterprise and its shareholders in the years ahead. Turning now to our hospital division. After two years of preparing for the implementation of LTAC criteria, as of September 1, all of our ongoing 82 hospitals were in criteria. We're pleased to be executing on our multifaceted mitigation strategy. During recent months, we completed a strategic sale, swap, or closure of 20 LTACs, substantially completing this portfolio optimization component of our strategy to maximize the positioning and efficiency of our go-forward portfolio. Early market feedback is confirming our multifaceted LTAC criteria mitigation strategy is working. Referral sources are embracing the clarity of LTAC criteria, as well as being appreciative of our desire to accept both post-intensive care compliant patients as well as medically complex patients or site-neutral. Kindred's approach to saying yes to referral sources for all LTAC appropriate patients helped deliver admissions growth, not contraction, in the third quarter. While the quarterly only had a month and a half of criteria impact, the results provide an encouraging early read on criteria mitigation. For the same hospital portfolio, the growth in admissions were a positive 1%. The criteria-driven decrease in Medicare revenue for admission was mitigated by favorable mix and length of stay reduction to yield an overall 1% growth in same-hospital revenue. And the average length of stay in our medically complex patients continues to come down. While we expect to have more insight on criteria-related trends after our first full quarter, next quarter, the composition of our ongoing hospital division revenue we think is noteworthy. For the month of September, 86% of our ongoing hospital revenue came from compliant patients. The remaining 14% of revenue was from Medicare site-neutral patients. The unmitigated revenue impact of LTAC criteria for the ongoing portfolio in September was approximately $8 million. Given the vector on criteria we are seeing, we're confident in our ability to successfully navigate through this transition. And we continue to expect that by the end of 2017, on a run rate basis, we will mitigate roughly half of the impact of this reimbursement change. We are further encouraged by the fact that the degree of criteria challenges facing our portfolio of LTACs varies widely. To be clear, some LTACs are impacted by criteria more than others. We believe our ability to implement targeted strategies at each of our hospitals will yield favorable results. For example, in California we're the leading LTAC provider in the state. Commercial patients are reimbursed on a per diem basis. Our ability to focus on driving these patients without the previous LTAC qualifying 25-day length of stay requirement creates an enormous opportunity to fill our hospitals with a very profitable mix. And we're only hedging here because when we give out the information, we want it to be right, and we've got a lot of work to do in that regard. Operator Next A.J. Rice with UBS. A.J. Rice I have a few questions, if possible. First, Ben, just to clarify, so if we're looking at the EBITDAR and the skilled nursing this quarter, it looks like it's about $30 million; so assuming that's sort of a run rate, $120 million. When you are referencing the $70 million to $100 million of overhead, I know you've got a separate item in your segment data that has $50 million of corporate expense. Is the $70 million to $100 million in the allocation for the segment? Or is that somehow in some other bucket? Ben Breier I would say let me see how to phrase that. I would say much of the $70 million to $100 million is in the segment, but not all. A.J. Rice Okay. All right. And then you've obviously downsized your skilled nursing portfolio significantly already, so you probably have some history on this. I'm just wondering, how does getting out of the rest of it does it have any spillover effect in RehabCare? What's been the experience when RehabCare is servicing one of these some of these units that get sold or disposed of? Ben Breier Yes, good question; and we've given a lot of thought to that. And in the way we have thought about this transaction, let me tell you what we have sort of assumed. Typically our experience is is that when we have divested Kindred nursing center assets, we've kept about half of the RehabCare contracts. In this case, we've taken a conservative approach to thinking that we may lose as much as two thirds of that business. But we've also seen, for instance, in the sale of our LTACs to Curahealth, that they engaged us and wanted to keep all of that business with RehabCare. So it really is going to depend on a facility by facility basis what we keep or not. But, A.J. to your question, historically we've kept about half. A.J. Rice Okay. If whether it's a half or two thirds, whatever is there any way to size how much RehabCare business goes to those 90 facilities at this point? Ben Breier There is somewhere between about $8 million to $10 million of EBITDAR that we generate, A.J., from RehabCare coming from those facilities. You are talking about $4 million or $5 million. And we haven't really talked about it; you addressed it a little bit in the prepared remarks. But the commentary around labor, it sounds like most of that is in the skilled nursing. But it sounds like maybe a little is in LTAC, maybe even a little in home health. Can you just give us a little more flavor for what you are seeing on that? Ben Breier I don't think that our labor pressures are more remarkable or less remarkable than most healthcare providers out there. It is absolutely coming from the skilled nursing side, both in the skilled nursing industry, but I would argue more specifically from the skilled nursing, meaning the RN environment. And it's not even so much in the wage rates that we're having to pay, or signing bonuses that we're having to do, of which we have to do a lot of that it's really in what I would talk about the premium pay side of the world. It's paying overtime; it's finding registry nurses; it's finding nurses to fill shifts. It's a very tight labor market out there, A.J., and I think we're experiencing it. Some geographic pockets are worse than others. The skilled nursing industry seems to be worse than the hospital industry, which seems to be worse than the home health industry. And I would argue the hospice industry, for whatever reason, we are seeing a lot of premium pay nurses there. So, it's sort of widespread, but it's not everywhere. It's mostly on the skilled RN side. And we're working very hard to try and abate it. The best thing we can do obviously is to limit turnover and reduce that cycle of having to go out and recruit and have empty and open positions. And our human resource and people service team is working very hard around here to do that. Our unemployment I'm sorry, our turnover rates are kind of around the historical levels they've been. They've held pretty steady, even in a very tight labor market. But finding and being able to fill open positions has been a challenge, for sure. A.J. Rice Okay. And maybe just one last thing on the criteria. So, you are at 86% compliant today. I know your model isn't to get to 100% compliant. Your model is to continue to take some site-neutral patients. Two aspects of it. Do you have any sense, at this early stage, where you think that 86% ultimately shakes out? And you said that on the site-neutral, you are having some success in reducing length of stay, getting them into other sites on the continuum, I guess. Is there any early read on how much of a drop in length of stay, if you are historically fluctuating, I don't know how the site-neutrals historically have been, but around 25 day average length of stay, how much does that typically drop in the new reimbursement environment? Ben Breier Sure. Well, to your first question, A.J., this is just directional, but I think that over the course of the next two years of being in criteria, it will not surprise me, and I would think it would be likely that we would get over the 90% level on what we would call a compliant patient, or a non-site-neutral patient. I think that as I talked about the example of the growth in per diem commercial and other paying patients, as we continue to go after more Medicare full DRG patients and the market continues to understand the clarity of what an LTAC can be and can't be A.J., as we continue to take bed capacity out and see other customers probably moving out of the LTAC business, I would argue over the next year and a half or so, those things I think will lead us to probably moving north of 90% on the compliant side. On the length of stay side, look, I am a little hesitant to give too much data on that, only because it really is only a month, month and a half of it. But I would say to you that if you look at our statistics, you can see that our Medicare lengths of stay came down by almost a full day, and that's with only really a month and a half of criteria in it. And I would say that that is predominantly being driven by lengths of stay dropping in those site-neutral patients. And it wouldn't surprise me if, over time, those site-neutral patients came down three, four, maybe even as many as five days, over the next two years. Before all is said and done. A.J. Rice All right, great. Thanks a lot. Operator We will next to Gary Taylor with JPMorgan. Gary Taylor Most of my questions were answered; just wanted to hit a couple details. Just going back to the last topic on the site-neutral patients, you talk about 14% of revenue. Can you share percent of admissions or percent of patient days on that? Ben Breier I don't know that we've segmented that out, Gary. I'm looking at my guys. It's probably a little bit less than the 86%, but not markedly different, but a little bit less. Obviously the rates on the fully compliant patients are going to be higher than on the nons, so revenue is going to be a little bit higher than what patient days would be. But we haven't disclosed that yet. But probably after the first quarter when we have a little more detail, we will do that. Gary Taylor And the length of stay on the noncompliant patients, I think in your last answer you said, down three days. I want to make sure I understood that correctly. So, on the noncompliant patients, they are running in the low 20s? Is that what you are trying to convey? Ben Breier Yes, I didn't say they were down yet three days. I think the question was, where did I think they would get? But what I quoted, just to be clear, because I think it's important, our Medicare lengths of stay in total came down by about a day. A large portion of that, I would argue most of that, driven by the noncompliant, if you will; the site-neutral, medically complex. And then the question was asked, well, where did I think it would go? And I said, based on the data I'm seeing, I think that can come down by three to as many as five days on that total book of business over the next couple of quarters. Gary Taylor That's on total Medicare length of stay on that part. Ben Breier On the medically complex, on the site-neutral. Gary Taylor And then just going back to the question about; again the overhead question, just because it's important as we try to think about ongoing earnings power of the Company. Of the $70 million to $100 million of overhead, you said much of that is loaded into the SNF segment, but not all. Can you be more precise on that? As we're modeling and thinking about valuation, we're taking the SNF EBITDAR out of the model. What should we be thinking about in terms of shared services overhead reduction? Ben Breier Look, the best way I can answer this, Gary -- and I know I got a lot -- we'll do a lot more details after the fact -- is to say, you got about $120 million plus of EBITDAR in the nursing center business. You know $90 million of rents are going to come out. So, included in the $120 million, to your point is, as I said, a lot but not all of that overhead number. We believe, having looked at the overhead rationalization that we will do in a very detailed way, that by the time we are done, we will have -- this will be an accretive action for this Company, an EBITDAR improving action for this Company. So, I know that doesn't leave you with all the details you want to model. But it does help fill that gap that, while some of the overhead -- a lot of the overhead is included in the $120 million in the division, there is more that will come out. And ultimately we believe it will be an EBITDAR accretive action that we will have taken when we're done. Gary Taylor Last question. On the rent, the $90 million rent associated with these facilities, obviously as Ventas has pointed out today, they have to consent to the sale. They have master leases that are also supported by LTACs in the market. And so, your confidence level that, on the portion that's related to Ventas, that you really do see that rent go away? We're not caught in another situation like we were a number of years ago, where because of those master leases, the total level of rent that you had to pay didn't come down as much. Does that make sense? Ben Breier I understand your question; I'm just not going to get into the details of a deal that's not yet done. But I will focus on the comments that Ventas made this morning in their release, and that we continue to believe that we will find a mutually beneficial negotiation here happen. And I understand your comments. And we take those quite seriously and importantly as it relates to our shareholders. And we will continue those conversations with our partners at Ventas here into the future. Gary Taylor One more question. Steve, when we look at the revenue eliminations at the corporate level, I think $52 million in this quarter, was the vast majority of that RehabCare revenues sold into the SNF segment? I realize not all of it would be related to these 90, but is that the bulk of the $52 million revenue eliminations? Stephen Farber Gary, we're looking. Just making sure we give you an answer. The short answer is yes, Gary. It's mostly from the rehab side. Operator We'll take our next question from Kevin Fischbeck with Bank of America Merrill Lynch. Kevin Fischbeck I appreciate the color on the impact to RehabCare from exiting the SNFs. Is there an impact on Kindred at Home? How much of the volume do you get there? And how does those referral patterns usually hold up after a divestiture? Ben Breier We don't imagine there's going to be much of an impact there, Kevin. It's a natural question you asked. We are driving a significant amount of referrals from those skilled nursing facilities into our home health operations. But on the scale of our 2-point-whatever billion-dollar home health operation, it's not a huge piece. And under any circumstances, those are relationships that we think will continue. So I wouldn't read too much into any degradation there. Kevin Fischbeck Okay. And then it's still a little bit confusing to me, exactly how to think about the puts and takes around the adjustment to Q4 guidance. If we could maybe separate them into things that are related to the nursing home business that you are going to get rid of, and the things that are going to be persisting. Obviously the LTAC, it sounds like a $5 million headwind, something that maybe we should annualize into next year if that's going to be an ongoing thing. But the $40 million to $50 million labor dynamic, it sounds like most of it is SNFs, but maybe not all of it. Is there a portion, can you give us some granularity about how much of that is purely nursing home, and how much of that is related to businesses you are going to be keeping, going forward? Ben Breier Sure. So let me try and qualify the numbers and clarify them a little bit, Kevin. And I'm sorry there's still some confusion out there. We've tried to be as clear as we could with it. Remember, the $40 million to $50 million that we were talking about reflected back to the initial 2016 guidance we gave, and where we thought that business was going to be. And that included what we said was exposure to the skilled nursing industry, which meant there was a portion of that in our nursing center business and there was a portion of that coming from our RehabCare business, which had a fairly tough third quarter. And we see some of that happening into Q4 with census coming down, and skill mix in some of our third-party nursing centers across the country. If you look at guidance in terms of what we did in Q4, and you say we took guidance from the midpoint of $990 million down to the midpoint of $960 million, there's a $30 million guidance move. You have to, at least in our math, take $10 million out; $5 million of which is related to criteria, and $5 million of it was related to the Curahealth hospitals coming out that were not in our guidance. And so you are talking about this $20 million delta, if you will, from midpoint to midpoint in our guidance for Q4. What I would argue is is that probably over half of that is related to the continued decline on our nursing center and RehabCare businesses that we see happening into Q4. And another good portion of that is related to these labor headwinds that we talked about. It's hard to quantify whether that's $12 million, $8 million, $10 million, $10 million, but something in that kind of mix is the way that I would be thinking about it in the way that we guided for Q4. Does that make sense? Kevin Fischbeck Yes. I think that that, I guess the question is, but if you think about Curahealth, obviously, the whole thing comes out next year. The $5 million from the LTAC, obviously we should annualize that into next year because of ongoing things. The half that's related to non-SNF, I guess we'll see how that develops over time. But it feels to me like you're saying that maybe something else actually got better, because we're talking 40 to 50, then we're talking about 20. And so, is there an offset somewhere? You had said that the IRF business is doing $5 million or $10 million better than you thought, or the home health business is doing $10 million better than you thought. How do we think about that? Ben Breier Yes. Yes, exactly. Our home health, hospice, and IRF businesses are doing better. We've managed, I think, SG&A in our corporate, our support center costs better. We're not just living in a static environment. We're trying to do better at the businesses that are growing. And we have, in fact, seen improvement in these growing businesses. So, yes, that's the offset to why the guidance was taken to where it was taken, and not anything incremental from that. Kevin, we've got to jump. We have time for one more, I think here. We're already running over. Thank you. Operator Will take our next question from Gary Lieberman with Wells Fargo. Gary Lieberman Within the LTAC, if we just looked at the Medicare book of business, what was your compliance rate there? Was it higher than the 86% overall? Ben Breier No. Gary, if you take the Medicare book of business alone, we ran a compliant rate somewhere in the mid 60s, I would say, just on the Medicare business alone. So remember, though, the math on that is that's so let's call it 65% of 60%, whatever that math turns into, is the part of our total. So it's about mid-60s on the Medicare mix. Gary Lieberman Okay. And then if I look at my math, I don't know if I'm doing it right, but it looks like average daily census on the Medicare book of business was down, like, 85 days. Should I think about that as one month impact? Or is that I heard you mention or reference a month and a half of impact. What is the right way to think about it? Ben Breier Probably a month and a half. We had all of our for two weeks in August, anything that was in house that stayed in house through September 1, wound up being coded under LTAC criteria. So I think it's a month and a half, probably is the right way to look at that. Gary Lieberman Okay. And then the impact from the overhead of exiting the SNF business, is the right way to think about it if we look at the line item that you report as the support center, which was $250 million of expense last year is that where it largely is? Or how should we think about it? Ben Breier No, Gary. And again, we promise we'll give more details as you guys are trying to model, as we move through this. Remember, the so there's a portion of it in that; but I would argue it's a smaller portion in that number, Gary. Most of it resides in the nursing center division's EBITDAR number that you already see. Remember, the overhead in that division flows right through its own EBITDAR number. So when the question was asked to me, what percentage of the $70 million to $120 million of savings is already in the division versus in that corporate number of you quoted, I said most but not all. So, we will obviously be reducing significant amounts of overhead inside the division. And there will be other overhead around shared services and other that will come out that is, in fact, in that line item that you just quoted. Make sense? Gary Lieberman Okay. That's very helpful. All right, thanks very much. Ben Breier Thank you all very much. All right, operator. I think we're going to have to close it there. Operator All right, Mr. Breier, I'll turn it back to you for closing. Ben Breier Thank you very much. Thank you. I know it was a busy quarter, a lot to announce. We appreciate everybody's interest in the Company, and I hope continued support. We think we have a good plan, and we're going to go out and execute it. And we'll look forward to talking to you about our progress next quarter. Thank you all very much. Copyright policy: All transcripts on this site are the copyright of Seeking Alpha. Acadia ( ACAD ) was upgraded to buy from neutral at Bank of America/Merrill Lynch. The valuation is more attractive, based on a $35 price target, analysts said.

November 29, 2016 – 2:10 p.m. ET

Clearwater Paper manufactures quality consumer tissue, away-from-home tissue, parent roll tissue, bleached paperboard and pulp at manufacturing facilities across the nation. Clearwater Paper's employees build shareholder value by developing strong customer partnerships through quality and service.

thread.title: IBM Upgraded To Buy; Bank Of America Sees Multiple Levers To Drive Growth
thread.title_full: IBM Upgraded To Buy; Bank Of America Sees Multiple Levers To Drive Growth

posts.author: Jim Swanson
posts.title: IBM Upgraded To Buy; Bank Of America Sees Multiple Levers To Drive Growth
posts.text:
Bank Castles Of Sand: Blockchain Edition (Seeking Alpha) 
International Business Machines Corp. (NYSE: IBM ) has been making significant investments in M&A and restructuring. With the pace of these investments expected to decline and IBM poised to benefit from these efforts, the company faces “multiple levers to drive earnings growth in 2017,” Bank of America Merrill Lynch’s Wamsi Mohan said in a report. 
Mohan upgraded the rating on the company from Neutral to Buy, while raising the price target from $170 to $185. Reasons For Upgrade 
Mohan mentioned ten reasons for upgrading IBM to Buy: Earnings seem to have stabilized, and large negative revisions are unlikely. Cash flow per share would likely be flat or up in 2017. IBM’s dividend yield of 3.6 percent appears attractive “when accounting for the optionality of success in growth markets like Artificial Intelligence.” The company would face tailwinds in 2017 from lower restricting charges and savings from restructuring efforts. IBM is unlikely to increase its pace of investments, resulting in benefits from increased utilization SaaS revenues would begin contributing to a higher percentage of growth. The slowdown in IBM’s constant currency organic growth is likely to moderate and could turn to positive in 2018. Mainframe cycle in 2017 could drive a recovery in transactional revenues. “CIO survey suggests IBM gaining mindshare in business intelligence, analytics and Watson .” The company’s shares are currently trading at a discount on earnings to peers. 
Minutes after Thursday's opening bell, IBM was up 2.51 percent at $158.70. Latest Ratings for IBM

thread.title: Buy IBM on stabilizing earnings, solid dividend, Bank of America says
thread.title_full: Buy IBM on stabilizing earnings, solid dividend, Bank of America says

posts.title: Buy IBM on stabilizing earnings, solid dividend, Bank of America says
posts.text:
Scott Eells | Bloomberg | Getty Images A pedestrian walks past International Business Machines Corp. (IBM) offices in New York, U.S. 
Bank of America Merrill Lynch on Thursday upgraded IBM to buy from neutral, listing a plethora of positive catalysts such as stabilizing earnings and a 3.6 percent dividend yield, which could propel the stock 20 percent higher in the next 12 months. 
"We view IBM as a defensive investment given its high exposure to recurring sales, cost cutting levers, solid balance sheet, potential share gains and relatively stable margins," equity analyst Wamsi Mohan wrote in a note to clients. "We believe 2016 should be a bottom for earnings and FCF [free cash flow], and positively view its improving fundamentals." 
Since hitting a six-year low in February, shares of IBM are already up 32 percent as value investors have scooped up the stock.

posts.title: Bank of America shares surging for second day, touching 2010 heights
posts.text:
November 10, 2016 10:26 AM Bank of America shares surging for second day, touching 2010 heights Surging for a second day after Donald Trump’s election win, Bank of America shares reached prices in trading on Thursday last seen in 2010. Mark Kauzlarich Bloomberg i Order Reprint of this Story 
Surging for a second day after Donald Trump’s election win, Bank of America shares are trading Thursday at prices last seen in 2010. 
Around 10:15 a.m., the shares were up more than 4 percent to $18.74. The Charlotte-based bank’s stock last saw these heights in the spring of 2010 and last closed above $18 in July 2015. 
Bank shares generally are rising for a second day on prospects of lighter regulation in a Trump administration, including changes to the Dodd-Frank financial reform law signed by President Barack Obama. 
In a report Thursday, analysts with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods said Trump’s victory creates many opportunities but also risks for bank stocks. The possibility of less regulation is among opportunities, the report notes, but it adds there is also much uncertainty about what a Trump presidency will mean for banks. Restrictions on trade will be a negative for U.S. economic growth, which could mean less lending that would especially impact Bank of America and other mega banks, the report says. 
“We know very little about president-elect Trump's policies that will impact financials since ... priorities outside of trade, terrorism, and immigration were mentioned less,” the report says. 
Even Wells Fargo, which is reeling from a sales scandal , is riding the wave. Shares of the San Francisco-based bank, which maintains its biggest employment hub in Charlotte, were up more than 4 percent in mid-morning trading to $50.24. Wells shares closed Wednesday at $47.99, above their $49.77 closing price Sept. 7, the day before authorities fined it $185 million over its sales practices. 
Across Wall Street, other stocks are also opening higher Thursday as the rebound in share prices around the world continued two days after Trump’s election. 
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 142 points, or 0.7 percent, to 18,731 shortly after the opening bell. 
The S&P 500 index was up 13 points, or 0.6 percent, to 2,176. The Nasdaq composite rose 31 points, or 0.6 percent, to 5,282. 
Banks and other financial stocks rose the most, while utilities and real estate stocks lost ground. 
The Associated Press contributed

thread.title: JPMorgan Chase: Time For a Pause?
thread.title_full: JPMorgan Chase: Time For a Pause? - Stocks to Watch - Barrons.com

posts.author: Ben Levisohn
posts.title: JPMorgan Chase: Time For a Pause?
posts.text:
By Ben Levisohn After watching JPMorgan Chase ( JPM ), Bank of America ( BAC ), and Bank of New York Mellon ( BK ) and other universal banks surge yesterday , KBW’s Brian Kleinhanzl and Michael Brown worry that banking stocks could be ready for a pause. They explain why:
Getty Images Universal Bank stocks rose 5.0%, on average, today as bank and most financial stocks were up strong on the prospects of better economic growth, higher interest rates , and less regulation under a Donald Trump administration. The move was surprising to us given how much uncertainty remains surrounding potential policies from the new administration.
Absolute P/Es Stretching: The current P/E multiples for Universal Banks are all above the average since 2010 for each individual bank, and JPM has reached the peak P/E multiple since 2010. We believe that P/E multiples could go above the peak P/E multiple since 2010 but there would need to be clearer signs about regulatory relief than what we have currently…
Positioning Post the Rally: Given the optimism built into the share prices after the rally today, we would not be surprised to see stocks pause, or pull back, until clearer signs emerge regarding regulatory benefits or future economic growth catalysts. At this time, we are still looking to own high quality Universal Bank stocks and Bank of New York Mellon is our top pick followed by JPMorgan. Bank of New York Mellon is less exposed to a potential reinstatement of Glass-Steagall given the lack of a true consumer banking franchise. We also believe that Bank of New York Mellon will benefit more than Universal Bank peers from higher rates given the company’s shorter duration securities portfolio (about 2 years), and we already expected the net interest margin to trough prior to the move up in long-term rates today. For JPMorgan, we continue to believe that the company will be able to improve returns even without regulatory relief, so if the company did see less regulation then that would be additive. We also believe that both stocks would fare better than peers should a pullback occur.
Shares of JPMorgan Chase have gained 3.1% to $75.50 at 11:39 a.m. today, while Bank of New York Mellon has ticked up 0.1% to $45.58, and Bank of America has risen 2.3% to $18.38.

thread.title: After Bank Of America's 'Yuge' Rally, I'm Ringing The Register
thread.title_full: After Bank Of America's 'Yuge' Rally, I'm Ringing The Register

posts.title: After Bank Of America's 'Yuge' Rally, I'm Ringing The Register
posts.text:
BAC is up two dollars this week. 
Rates are pricing in the December hike already and I worry about catalysts. 
And at years' high valuations, I'm worried about how far BAC and other banks have come. Photo credit The man pictured above has stunned the world and won the US presidency. While this is not a political article of any kind, the simple fact is that investors thought Clinton would win on Tuesday and that meant that bank stocks (along with some others like Biotech) were toxic. With the President-Elect's fresh victory, however, bank stocks are flying and for many of the largest, hitting levels that are multi-year or all-time highs. One such stock is my long time favorite in the group, Bank of America (NYSE: BAC ). BAC has stayed the course with its strategy of de-risking and operating under the umbrella of safety and soundness and it seems that is finally paying off. But has it paid off a little too well? Has BAC come too far, too fast? Click to enlarge My first exhibit for this exercise is a five-year weekly chart of BAC that shows the extraordinary amount of time this stock has languished. We see lots of bouncing around - plenty of trading opportunities - but for long term holders, the past few years have been frustrating to say the least. But this week, on the back of Trump's win, BAC has broken out to levels it hasn't seen since the financial crisis. The gravity of that cannot be overstated and for me - a long term bull on this stock - it feels like vindication. After all, I've been pounding the table for years on BAC and finally, the stock is showing some life. The thing is that nothing material has changed in BAC's outlook since the election. The only thing that happened was that Clinton - who was seen as "anti-big bank" - was defeated and rates have come up a bunch. Again, I'm not here to argue about candidates but the simple fact of the matter is that Trump is better for the financials than Clinton would have been; just look at they way they've traded for the past two days. But is that enough for a mid-teens rally in two days? If we zoom in and look at the daily chart for the past year, we can see the rapidity with which BAC has moved up in the past couple of days. In fact, since the beginning of November, BAC has gone from $16.50 to nearly $19. That's an extraordinary move and while I love it, I have to wonder if the animal spirits are a little too wild these days. Is sentiment too good on the banks right now? This chart makes me think so. Click to enlarge The charts of the other big banks look pretty similar to this and if you just think about the enormity of the idea of these stocks making multi-year highs, you can appreciate the extraordinary time we are witnessing. It seems the days of banks being in the doghouse with investors have come and gone in a flash of boisterous talk and perfectly manicured hair. And that does something very important; it frees up investors to pay more than 9 times forward earnings for bank stocks, something investors as a whole haven't been particularly willing to do in the past few years. Rates have moved up a bunch in the past two days as the 10Y is now around 2.12% after starting the week at just over 1.8%. That's a huge move (or maybe even yuge ) for something as hard to move as the 10Y Treasury and while I welcome this move as a bank stock holder, I have to wonder how much staying power it has. After all, I believe the Fed will raise rates in December but I also believe it will be another 6 months or so before we get another one. The move up in rates we've just seen has fully priced in the December hike; what will be the catalyst for the next several months until the Fed talks about hiking again? Chair Yellen is very cautious and I suspect it will take a gargantuan effort from the FOMC to hike again anytime soon. Click to enlarge Bonds are extremely oversold right now and while I get the idea of the selloff, the magnitude and speed of it has been something to behold. US Treasury charts don't normally look like this and I'm worried the move up is a knee-jerk reaction that will have to be consolidated at best or somewhat retraced at worst. Again, if we're already pricing in a December hike, where's the catalyst for a further move up? BAC is as overbought as it has been for years and that means that consolidation must happen; there is no possible way for buyers to keep the pressure up like it has been for the past two days. That consolidation will likely include at least one retest of the $18 area that was such strong resistance for the past couple of years and what happens then will be paramount; does BAC break down and enter back into its channel or bounce and make a sustainable move higher? I think the answer is the latter but that doesn't stop me from thinking that BAC has come too far, too fast. I've been a steadfast bull on Bank of America for a long time but right now, I think it is time to ring the register and wait for a better price. Is BAC 15% better off today than it was on Monday? Maybe, but you'd have a hard time convincing me of that. The fact that Clinton didn't win is a victory for the banks but as I said, the December hike (and possibly more) has already been priced into rates and bank stocks. That leaves no catalysts other than organic growth and cost savings - two things BAC is doing a nice job of - until the next rate hike sometime next year. It's not that I'm not bullish on BAC any longer, it is just that we've seen months and months of gains accrue in two days so I'm a little cautious. When stocks like BAC and JPM move like they have this week, strange things are happening. After all, when was the last time BAC went for 12 times forward earnings ? That multiple has been reserved for bank royalty in the past few years but those companies are going for even higher multiples. Given that the outlook for ROE and earnings hasn't really changed but valuations have, I'm a lot more cautious today than I was on Monday. I think investors have gotten really excited and that means I'm ringing the register here. I'll buy back into BAC in relatively short order if it pulls back as I think it will. If BAC continues to go up without me, so be it; the risk of a pullback outweighs the risk to the upside for a stock at a years' high valuation and extreme overbought condition. No matter how much I like a stock, there's always a point where it is too rich for my blood and right now, Bank of America is there. Disclosure: I/we have no positions in any stocks mentioned, and no plans to initiate any positions within the next 72 hours. I wrote this article myself, and it expresses my own opinions. I am not receiving compensation for it (other than from Seeking Alpha). I have no business relationship with any company whose stock is mentioned in this article. Additional disclosure: I will reenter my BAC long position upon a pullback About this article: Expand Author payment: $35 + $0.01/page view. Authors of PRO articles receive a minimum guaranteed payment of $150-500. Become a contributor » Tagged: Financial , Regional - Mid-Atlantic Banks

thread.title_full: T.E.N. Announces Winners at the ISE North America Awards - CBS News 8 - San Diego, CA News Station - KFMB Channel 8

posts.author: cbs8
posts.title: T.E.N. Announces Winners at the ISE North America Awards
posts.text:
Executives and projects from AT&T, Bank of America, Change Healthcare , Columbia University, New York City Health + Hospitals, and U.S. Bancorp receive top honors during North America’s most prestigious security award program.
Chicago, IL
T.E.N., a technology and information security executive networking and relationship-marketing firm, honored finalists and winners Tuesday evening at the 2016 ISE® North America Leadership Summit and Awards Gala at the Westin Michigan Avenue in Chicago, IL.
The ISE® North America awards recognize both information security executives and project teams for outstanding achievements in risk management, data asset protection, compliance, privacy and network security. Award program participants are located across the U.S. and Canada, and nominations were considered within four categories based on industry classification, including Academic/Public Sector, Commercial, Financial Services and Health Care.
“We were amazed by the accomplishments of our executive and project nominees,” said Marci McCarthy, CEO and president, T.E.N. “The executives nominated include the industry’s brightest minds and many of the projects are game changers. This year’s nominees represent the future of security innovation.”
Academic/Public Sector Category
Medha Bhalodkar, Medha Bhalodkar is the Chief Information Security Officer of Columbia University and has served as the university's first CISO since 2006. Medha has over 25 years of experience in various aspects of Information Technology, Security, Auditing and Risk Management, spending over 15 years in the Financial Industry and over 10 years in the Education and Healthcare industry. She is a recognized Risk Management and Information Security professional and serves on a number of governing bodies, steering committees of professional organizations and is a frequent panel speaker at major NY conferences. Medha has a number of security certifications (e.g., CISA, CGEIT, CRISC, CICA, ITIL, and Cloud Security Certifications) and a B.S. from Bombay University. Medha is proud of her role as a woman in IT and strives to mentor and guide young women this profession.
The “Perimeterless Network Security” project, submitted by Columbia University, was selected as the ISE® North America Project of the Year in the Academic/Public Sector Category. This project achieved our prime goal of providing information security where needed, at the same time support the basic mission of the University of sharing of information in an open network to promote exchange of ideas and research. Columbia University is a blend of Corporate and ISP elements that as such, requires a security structure that covers these requirements. We also have strict security requirements for protecting our intellectual property and applications such as payroll, human resources, financial and student records. Our goal in implementing this project was to improve our security posture by leveraging implementation of CUIT’s Converged Infrastructure project, while it was being designed, developed, and deployed, and support university mission to allow free exchange of information.
Commercial Category
Bill O'Hern, Senior Vice President and Chief Security Officer for AT&T, was selected as the Information Security Executive® of the Year Award winner in the Commercial Category. His twenty-year career at AT&T has been primarily focused on networking and information security, with a particular focus on innovative security platforms within AT&T's Enterprise, Commercial and Federal Government environments. Bill helped build the first scalable internal Threat Management System currently used by AT&T to monitor and defend its network and computing infrastructure; he is also the lead for our Security Virtualization and Software Defined Network (SDN) approach. In addition, Bill previously had responsibility for our AT&T Security Policy and Requirements, Penetration Testing, Security Architecture and Risk Management functions. He is responsible for the strategic thought leadership and technology evolution of AT&T’s capabilities, primarily focused on leveraging our vast global network and operational capabilities. This includes the migration to our next generation software defined networking efforts as well as our emerging services in iOT and Entertainment. Finalists included John Graham, Chief Information Security Officer of Jabil and Pritesh Parekh, VP & Chief Security Officer of Zuora.
The ISE® North America Project of the Year in the Commercial Category was AT&T’s “AT&T Identity and Access Management Platform;” where AT&T’s security experts have built a proprietary technology that helps simplify and secure the authentication process. Finalists included the Cox Automotive’s project “Rugged DevOps” and Best Western Hotels and Resorts’ project “Best Western Business Transformation Project”.
Financial Services Category
Craig Froelich, Chief Information Security Officer at Bank of America, was selected as the Information Security Executive® of the Year Award winner in the Financial Services Category. Craig is responsible for the firm’s customers, clients and employees from cyber risks and threats and has led the company’s security technology, operations, insider threat and information protection programs.
The U.S. Bancorp’s project “U.S. Bank Enterprise Tokenization Integration Project” was selected as the ISE® North America Project of the Year in the Financial Services Category. U.S. Bank Enterprise Tokenization Integration Project is a highly complex development project that required mapping of data-flows between applications, partnership with multiple CIOs who had to change applications in specifically orchestrated sequences, and business process re-engineering to remove or reduce use-cases where business processes were formerly using real data that required significant protective controls around it. The result was a dramatic reduction in data that required protection. Finalists included the Suntrust Bank’s project “2015 DR Next Project”, Elavon’s project “SecurityON” and PayPal’s project “Enterprise Vulnerability Management Program”.
Health Care Category
Vikrant Arora, AVP & Chief Information Security & Risk Officer at New York City Health + Hospitals, was selected as the Information Security Executive® of the Year Award winner in the Health Care Category. Vikrant is a credentialed business leader with over 10 years of global experience in developing enterprise security & risk management programs, delivering security “business value” and communicating risk to the BODs. Vikrant has successfully helped Government, Education and Healthcare sectors to become more resilient against future attacks and shift corporate culture accordingly.
Change Healthcare’s “TITAN - Threat Intelligence Tactical Analysis Network” was selected as the ISE® North America Project of the Year in the Health Care Category. The project was a threat intelligence and analysis network which enables pro-active, threat-based defense, threat analysis, identification, and tracking. Aetna’s projects “Inbound Email Protection” and “Audit Evidence Locker” and Quest Diagnostics’ project “Capture the Flag Hacker Challenge” were finalists in this category.
People’s Choice Award
V.Jay LaRosa, Vice President, Global Security Architecture for ADP, was named the ISE® North America People’s Choice Award Winner. This award represents the nominee who best exemplifies information security leadership as voted on by peers in information security.
Luminary Leadership Award
Also honored during Tuesday’s awards program was the 2016 Luminary Leadership Award winner Jim Routh, Chief Security Officer for Aetna. Presented annually, the award celebrates the achievements of an outstanding leader and industry practitioner for his or her distinguished service, stewardship and contributions in advancing the information security industry.
Full list of nominees can be found on the T.E.N. website:
Executive: http://ten-inc.com/ise/north_america/exec_nominees.asp
Project: http://ten-inc.com/ise/north_america/project_nominees.asp
About T.E.N.
T.E.N., a national technology and security executive networking organization, facilitates peer-to-peer relationships between top executives, industry visionaries and solutions providers. Nominated for numerous industry awards, T.E.N.’s executive leadership programs enable information exchange, collaboration and decision-making. Its flagship program, the nationally-acclaimed Information Security Executive® (ISE®) of the Year Program Series and Awards, is North America’s largest leadership recognition and networking program for security professionals. Other offerings include The ISE® Lions’ Den and Jungle Lounge, T.E.N. Custom Programs and the ISE® Industry Expert Advisory Services, empowering IT solutions providers to gain access to highly credentialed IT business veterans’ expertise.
About ISE® Award Program Series
For more than a decade, the Information Security Executive® (ISE®) of the Year Award Program Series has empowered security executives and their project teams to Connect, Collaborate and Celebrate. Recognized as the industry’s most prestigious IT Security award program, it has become the most anticipated award program for security executives and their project teams because it offers opportunities to benchmark against other leading security programs, while providing a channel for well-deserved recognition and visibility. Winners have included executives and project teams from leading organizations such as Nike, The Walt Disney Company, the United States Postal Service, Schlumberger, Texas Instruments, JPMorgan Chase & Co., Equifax, Comcast, PayPal, Northrop Grumman Corporation, and Nationwide.
Our distinguished ISE® Judges are past nominees representing a cross section of industries, including commercial, government, health care and academic sectors. For this reason, the ISE® Awards represent the best achievements of the year as evaluated by those regarded as the industry's most influential and successful thought leaders. Coupled with a one or two-day executive summit, the ISE® Awards are held across the country in major cities including Atlanta, Dallas, San Francisco, New York and Chicago. The ISE® Awards Program Series has reached more than 10,000 executives across a broad range of industries and has been a major influence in executives’ careers, knowledge sharing, and the development of peer-to-peer relationships.
 //www.prweb.com/releases/2016/11/prweb13832535.htm

thread.title: JPMorgan Hits Record As Banks Extend Gains; CEO Dimon At Treasury?
thread.title_full: JPMorgan Hits Record As Banks Extend Gains; CEO Dimon At Treasury? | Stock News & Stock Market Analysis - IBD

posts.author: BILL PETERS
posts.title: JPMorgan Hits Record As Banks Extend Gains; CEO Dimon At Treasury?
posts.text:
Big banks like JPMorgan Chase ( JPM ) , Bank of America ( BAC ) and Citigroup ( C ) continued their postelection stock-market surge on Thursday, amid rising odds for less regulation, higher inflation and Fed rate hikes next year.
CNBC also reported that JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon is being considered for Treasury secretary.
Shares of JPMorgan rallied 4.6% to close at 76.65 in the stock market today , setting a record high. Bank of America surged 4.4% to 18.76, blowing past buy range after breaking out Wednesday. Citigroup rose 3.9% to 53.61, reaching the highest in 11 months.
Wells Fargo ( WFC ) leapt 7.6%, adding to Wednesday's 5.4% pop. Goldman Sachs ( GS ) climbed 4.3% and Morgan Stanley ( MS ) gained 4.1%.
The U.S. 10-year Treasury yield added 7 basis points to 2.14% after skyrocketing Wednesday.
IBD'S TAKE: Bank stocks have jumped, and the Dow has touched an all-time high following Trump's victory. So have other infrastructure-spending-friendly stocks , like construction companies. 
Thursday's stock gains follow a strong performance for banking on Wednesday, amid greater anticipation that President-elect Donald Trump and a GOP-controlled Congress would work to curb industry regulations, including potentially gutting Dodd-Frank.
After a wild, toxic, stressful presidential campaign in which the big banks were often a punching bag, analysts have also said Trump's more cordial, evenhanded victory speech — and its focus on a massive infrastructure overhaul — helped lift markets Wednesday after being pressured in the run-up to Election Day.
Analysts have said Trump's focus on tax cuts and public infrastructure spending could bring higher inflation on a flood of new debt coming to the market and higher bond yields.
The rising inflation, along with the current market rally, have also helped shore up the odds that the Federal Reserve might raise the benchmark interest rate , potentially boosting banks' net-interest margins.
Trump's election, however, doesn't come without risks to the banking sector, analysts note.
"The opportunities come primarily from a steepening yield curve, increased volatility and reduced regulation," Keefe, Bruyette & Woods said in a research note. "The risks come from a retrenchment of the U.S. from the global economy and trade agreements."
In a separate note, KBW said it was "more cautious" on Citigroup, given the company's exposure to Mexico, a country that could be among the most vulnerable if Trump shreds existing U.S. trade pacts.
Citigroup in September said it saw "tremendous untapped potential" in Mexico.
