thread.title: The Shoe Has Dropped - Low Vol ETF Sees Largest Outflow On Record
thread.title_full: The Shoe Has Dropped - Low Vol ETF Sees Largest Outflow On Record - One News Page

posts.author: onenewspage.com
posts.title: The Shoe Has Dropped - Low Vol ETF Sees Largest Outflow On Record
posts.text:
One month ago, we cautioned readers that according to recent fund flow data, Bank of America was convinced that the "*next shoe to drop" *would be so-called "low-vol" stocks, ETFs and related strategies, which due to their debt-like characteristics and steady dividend payouts, had emerged as one of the preferred hangouts during the period of turbulent in the early part of the year.

As BofA Savita Subramanian explained, low volatility strategies had seen a parabolic increase in inflows since late 2014 as investors chased the perceived safety of these strategies. These inflows helped push valuations in Staples and Utilities to elevated levels. 

However, the stratgist warned , investor sentiment appears to be shifting from a deflation / low growth theme, which benefited defensives and yield plays in 1H16, to an inflation theme, with interest rates rising, inflation expectations picking up and fiscal stimulus beneficiaries attracting investor interest. As such, Utilities and Staples, which have been two preferred sectors for low vol strategies, were two of the worst performing sectors (along with Telecom) in Q3.

In August, Low Vol funds experienced their first outflow since September of 2014 and appear vulnerable to more outflows if their perceived safety deteriorates as investors shift their focus away from ZIRP (zero interest rate policy) beneficiaries.

As a result of these shifts, BofA concluded, “low vol” has become more risky: the realized volatility of low beta stocks has seen a steady increase over the past several years as shown in the chart below, suggesting low vol is becoming high vol.

Ironically, "low vol" was becoming "very high vol."

And then, after last week's victory by Donald Trump which unleashed the great Trumpflation rally, the not so low vol went off the charts, and the shoe officially dropped, and as Bloomberg pointed out earlier today, the "Low Vol" iShares Edge MSCI Min Vol EAFE ETF saw a record one-day outflow of more than $300 million on Wednesday.

The first warning was June's Brexit vote: "Brexit killed low-volatility — that was the catalyst. People just breathed a sigh of relief after that point," said Eric Balchunas, ETF analyst at Bloomberg Intelligence. However, thanks to the market's brisk rebound after Brexit courtesy of central bank backstops, the scare was not enough, and investors continued to flock inside into the "safety" of low vol ETFs, boosted by the funds' better performance than the overall market in the first half of 2016.

However, as Bank of America noted last month, the low vol outperformance ended some time around mid-July, at which point the group started to underperform the S&P.

As Brean Capital's Head of Macro Strategy Peter Tchir put it after the fact, "something got lost in translation. People, I think, started viewing it as 'all the upside of equities with limited downside' — they got the opposite — time to sell. This product attracted extremely risk averse investors — when risk popped up here 'unexpectedly' (I think completely predictably) the holders now sell as they didn't want risk in the first place."

So is it safe to write out "low vol" as a strategy? As long as the Trumpflation-inspired selloff in bonds continues and yields - together with the dollar - keep soaring, the answer for both dividend and "low vol" strategies is a resounding yes. However, once financial conditions as a result of the unprecedented chase of coming inflation (which as we explained earlier may not come at all, and will likely only arrive some time in 2018) become so tight that not even the quant community can keep chasing momentum with incremental leverage, all the money that is currently flooding out of the abovementioned products will rush right back in, and the cycle can begin from scratch.

organizations.name: brean capital's head of macro strategy peter tchir

thread.title: Bank Of America's 2017 Largely Depends On Trump And The Fed
thread.title_full: Bank Of America's 2017 Largely Depends On Trump And The Fed

posts.title: Bank Of America's 2017 Largely Depends On Trump And The Fed
posts.text:
Bank Of America's 2017 Largely Depends On Trump And The Fed Nov.17.16 Summary 
While this year started a bit rocky, Bank of America has had a solid 5 year performance. 
The largely republican shift in our government could represent a staunch shift from the more heavily regulated policies of the past 8 years. 
Combined with the Fed's recent acknowledgment of coming rate hikes, Bank of America's 2017 profits are an appealing play. 
Things are looking up 
The beginning of the year wasn't exactly what the doctor ordered for Bank of America (NYSE: BAC ). An opening quarter of declining earnings (yoy) is still an eye sore for shareholders. Thankfully, things are looking up. Q2 beat estimates, and Q3 created a trend. Not only did the bank beat expectations of a decline, they also outperformed the year prior. More encouraging is the return to revenue growth. The third quarter finally brought us increasing revenues; a welcome sight to shareholders. 
With interest rates that have been less than kind to financials over the past few years, Bank of America has kept a "big picture" appeal to investors. Interest income was shattered from 2011 onward , yet the bank managed to take earnings per share from a measly $0.01 in 2011 to $1.31 in 2015! Now with a republican congress and the man with a plan (well, we hope he has a plan) in as president elect, Bank of America could be primed for another step in the right direction. The big question is will congress work to create a less regulated banking environment? 
The future has some promise 
The banks future largely depends on which Donald Trump shows up. If it's the Donald that has criticized Janet Yellen , we "might" get higher rates. It's tough to tell considering the plethora of rhetoric he's given us in past months. My take away from all of Trump's statements on rates is that we should raise them the moment we see a lot of inflation developing. We've seen some higher inflation as of late. Perhaps we'll finally see a 1% rise. 
Whether you love it or hate it, lower financial regulations and higher rates could indeed open up avenues for higher gains for the banks. Assuming they don't free things up to the point that we end up in another 2008 scenario, shareholders are in a good spot right now. 
Today, Janet Yellen prompted my interest with a clearer rhetoric that interest rates will receive a bump sooner rather than later. I suspect this stance corresponds with Trump's election as it will become almost essential to raise rates should Trump's big spending ideas take shape. Regardless of the why, this is good news for banks like Bank of America. A rise in net interest incomes creates a big incentive to own this stock as revenues would surely receive a bump. The dividend is not attractive, but the Price to earnings is very competitive within the banking industry. Considering the stock growth through the last few years, it'll be interesting to see if higher rates can provide the fuel to keep this stock in the $20's. Disclosure: I/we have no positions in any stocks mentioned, and no plans to initiate any positions within the next 72 hours. I wrote this article myself, and it expresses my own opinions. thread.title: A 'violent rotation' is taking place in markets
thread.title_full: A 'violent rotation' is taking place in markets

posts.author: Akin Oyedele (aoyedele@businessinsider.com)
posts.title: A 'violent rotation' is taking place in markets
posts.text:
Clive Mason/Getty 
A "violent rotation" is taking place in the market, according to Bank of America Merrill Lynch. 
Since the election of Donald Trump, investors have pulled money out of bond funds and moved into equity funds at an unprecedented rate. 
If Trump's fiscal spending plans actualize, investors expect that they would lift domestic growth and inflation. The former could be good for stocks, while the latter would erode the expected returns on bonds. 
"If Brexit marked 5,000 year low in global interest rates, Trump marked [the] moment investors started to position for [a] bond bear market," said Michael Hartnett in the note. The UK voted to leave the European Union in June sent investors scrambling for the safety of bonds, sending yields lower. 
Fundstrat's Tom Lee said in a note on Friday that equity Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs) witnessed the some of the largest inflows in more than two years during the past two weeks. Also, outflows from bond ETFs last week ranked near the biggest ever.  
"Inflows into equity ETFs over the past two weeks are the largest since 2009 (~$50b) — investors have liquidated more than $2T of equities in the past decade and if such inflows are sustained, it would represent a significant tailwind for stocks," Lee said.  Clive Mason/Getty Hartnett said there was a record weekly inflow into financial-sector funds. Bank stocks have soared since Trump won  on bets that interest rates could rise, tax rates could fall, and some or all of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street reform law could be weakened or repealed.  Clive Mason/Getty 
The idea of a "great rotation" of funds from bonds to stocks has been touted in markets many times over the years, only for the bull market in bonds to rage on.
But in a note on Friday, Sean Darby, the chief global equity strategist at Jefferies, said — without using the phrase — that the great rotation is here. 
"Last week’s fund flow data may go down in history as the first real indication of the switch from bonds to equities," Darby said. 
Meanwhile, emerging-market assets have suffered big outflows. Investors pulled more money out of emerging-market equities on net that they have in 14 months. Emerging-market debt funds had the biggest weekly outflow ever.  Clive Mason/Getty 
Bond markets and currencies in Mexico, Brazil, Russia, and other countries sold off along with US Treasurys in the wake of the election.
Fixed-income flows tell the same story. Emerging-market debt ranked first last week in outflows as a percentage of assets under management.  Clive Mason/Getty

thread.title: Bank of America donates $200K to Delaware nonprofit
thread.title_full: Bank of America donates $200K to Delaware nonprofit

posts.title: Bank of America donates $200K to Delaware nonprofit
posts.text:
Bank of America donates $200K to Delaware nonprofit Jeff Mordock , The News Journal 8:57 a.m. EST November 18, 2016 Members of Communities in Schools for Delaware and Bank of America employees meet for a check presentation. (Photo: Courtesy of Bank of America) 1 CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Bank of America has selected Communities in Schools of Delaware, a nonprofit targeting schools in challenged neighborhoods, as its 2016 Neighborhood Builder. 
The bank will provide Communities in Schools of Delaware with a combination of leadership development, $2000,000 in flexible funding, a network of peer organizations across the United States and the opportunity to enhance their funding opportunities to expand their impact. 
For more than 20 years, Communities in Schools of Delaware has delivered its model of integrated support to children who face challenges both inside and outside the classroom. Communities in Schools of Delaware delivers critical community resources so that students can focus on learning, stay in school and graduate on time. The nonprofit targets schools in communities facing poverty, where more than 80 percent of the children are on free and reduced lunch. 
"The Neighborhood Builders grant will help them serve thousands more students who are at-risk of dropping out of school with increased funding for holistic programs that connect these students and their families to critical services like housing assistance, food and nutrition access, education, financial education, healthcare, mentors and much more," said Chip Rossi, Delaware market president for Bank of America. 
Carlton Lampkins, chairman of the board for Communities in Schools of Delaware, said the partnership with Bank of America will help those in need. 
"We work closely with schools, social services, businesses and thousands of volunteers to get young people the things they need to learn and grow: mentors and tutors, after-school help, and family service to stabilize the home. Without these basic supports, kids in need or high-risk are far less likely to succeed and grow into productive adults." 
Since 2004, through Neighborhood Builders, Bank of America has helped nonprofits impact the communities they serve. Through the program, Bank of America has invested more than $180 million in 900 nonprofit organizations throughout the country.

thread.title: Bank Of America: Quantifying The Trump Factor
thread.title_full: Bank Of America: Quantifying The Trump Factor

posts.title: Bank Of America: Quantifying The Trump Factor
posts.text:
Summary 
Analysts can find another 20% EPS in BAC with conservative adjustments to assumptions. 
BAC has been about cost reduction, but a bigger top line is worth more for EPS. 
Today the business has an improved outlook and investors enjoy a margin of safety. I've had a few questions along the lines of "ok, we'll see some more growth and inflation with Trump, but isn't this big move from the banks over the top?" The question is very reasonable. For a sector that has at times been treated with near revulsion by investors this year to suddenly pop raises eyebrows. As it happens though the answer is "no, the reaction is probably not over the top". This is mainly because, given the starting point, it won't take much to lift banks' EPS by 20%. With Bank of America (NYSE: BAC ) in focus I thought this is a good time to look at a few sensitivities for its bottom line. Everyone knows about Bank of America. The company is geared to higher rates but probably not as much as other banks we could find. I've thought the mid-term alpha from this stock would come from its improving operating leverage. That is, should the targets be delivered by 2018, it seemed unlikely BAC's cheapness over that forecast horizon would last, so it should outperform as its PE catches up with peers. After such an impressive run, it's a good idea to check out the numbers. One of the key elements of good long term investing is getting entry and exit levels broadly right and not to do much else with a position the rest of the time other than checking the investment case remains valid. How much is left for BAC and what should we assume as a new base case? Here is what I was looking for back on results day. On this outlook, BAC executes it cost reduction program pretty well, falling a little short of the $53bn target but well on the way there. Interest earning assets grow 4% annually, while net interest margin drops 10 bps to 2.1% for 2017 and is constant through 2018. Non interest income grows 3% in each of 2017 and 2018 and Loan loss provisions remain pretty flat. This is very much a low rates scenario with gentle pressure on NIM and constant benign credit costs, leaving the main drivers as modest asset and revenue growth and falling operating costs. This quiet outlook was worth a 19% lift in pre-provision profit and 21% on pre-tax by 2018. So is the market assuming a steroid injection from the Trump victory? Not really. What you can see in the short hand model above is that BAC doesn't need heroic assumptions to markedly improve its profit delivery. This is because every 1% improvement in income over flat cost is worth a 3% improvement at the pre-tax line. The same upside gearing works if we allow some more growth post Trump. In the above model, we used 4% growth in earning assets. Let's lift that to 6% in 2017-18 and raise NIM by 5bps in 2017 and by 10bps in 2018. For reference, the resulting NIM would be below what BAC achieved in 2011. Non interest income should grow a little faster too, given more economic activity in a growthier Trump world, so 3% growth goes out to 4 then 5%. More business activity will lift costs so that $53bn won't be achievable in the medium term, so we're looking at $55bn in 2018, while loan loss provision should also go up due to higher lending, though there is no reason to think in a buoyant growth environment that credit quality will deteriorate quickly (that will be a key sensitivity later in the cycle). While you might quibble with any of these changes, we are not starting from an expensive valuation so the stock isn't that vulnerable if you moderate the assumptions somewhat. Either way, here is what you get after these adjustments: If we put a 12x multiple on BAC for 2018, there's 35% upside before consideration of capital distribution, or a price target of $27 per share. Click to enlarge Conclusion BAC remains very attractive . On the numbers we've played with here, the stock has got a little less cheap in the past weeks moving from 8.2x EPS back on results day to 8.9x in 2018, but: so what? There's a lot left in BAC.
